title: Session 1: Environment Setup
text:
The shell is your command-line interface to Linux.

â”‚                       TERMINAL                          â”‚
â”‚  â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”  â”‚
â”‚  â”‚  user@hostname:~$  â† This is your PROMPT         â”‚  â”‚
â”‚  â”‚                                                   â”‚  â”‚
â”‚  â”‚  user     = your username                        â”‚  â”‚
â”‚  â”‚  hostname = computer name                        â”‚  â”‚
â”‚  â”‚  ~        = current directory (home)             â”‚  â”‚
â”‚  â”‚  $        = regular user (# for root)            â”‚  â”‚
â”‚  â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜  â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜






Shell
Description




bash
Bourne Again Shell - most common default


zsh
Z Shell - default on macOS, more features


fish
Friendly Interactive Shell - user-friendly


sh
Original Bourne Shell - basic, portable



Check your current shell:
echo $SHELL



/                       â† Root (top of everything)
â”œâ”€â”€ home/               â† User home directories
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ username/       â† Your files (~)
â”œâ”€â”€ etc/                â† System configuration files
â”œâ”€â”€ bin/                â† Essential user binaries
â”œâ”€â”€ usr/                â† User programs
â”‚   â”œâ”€â”€ bin/            â† User binaries
â”‚   â””â”€â”€ local/          â† Locally installed software
â”œâ”€â”€ var/                â† Variable files (logs, etc.)
â”œâ”€â”€ tmp/                â† Temporary files
â””â”€â”€ opt/                â† Optional/third-party software





pwd                 # Print Working Directory (where am I?)
ls                  # List files
ls -la              # List ALL files with details
cd /path/to/dir     # Change Directory
cd ~                # Go to home directory
cd ..               # Go up one level
cd -                # Go to previous directory



touch file.txt      # Create empty file
mkdir dirname       # Create directory
mkdir -p a/b/c      # Create nested directories
cp source dest      # Copy file
cp -r dir1 dir2     # Copy directory recursively
mv old new          # Move/rename
rm file             # Remove file
rm -rf dir          # Remove directory (CAREFUL!)



cat file.txt        # Display entire file
less file.txt       # Paginated view (q to quit)
head -n 10 file     # First 10 lines
tail -n 10 file     # Last 10 lines
tail -f file        # Follow file (live updates)



find . -name "*.py"           # Find files by name
grep "pattern" file.txt       # Search in file
grep -r "pattern" directory/  # Search recursively
which python                  # Find command location




Environment variables store system-wide settings.
# View all environment variables
env

# View specific variable
echo $PATH
echo $HOME
echo $USER

# Set a variable (current session)
export MY_VAR="hello"

# Set permanently (add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc)
echo 'export MY_VAR="hello"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc



PATH tells the system where to find executable programs.
echo $PATH
# Output: /usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/bin:/home/user/.local/bin

# When you type "python", system searches these directories in order
To add a new path:
export PATH="$PATH:/new/path/here"



ls -l file.txt
# -rw-r--r-- 1 user group 1234 Jan 17 10:00 file.txt
#  â””â”¬â”˜â””â”¬â”˜â””â”¬â”˜
#   â”‚  â”‚  â””â”€â”€ Others: read only
#   â”‚  â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ Group: read only  
#   â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€ Owner: read + write



Permission
Number
Meaning




r
4
Read


w
2
Write


x
1
Execute



chmod 755 script.sh   # rwxr-xr-x (owner: all, others: read+execute)
chmod +x script.sh    # Add execute permission





sudo apt update              # Update package list
sudo apt upgrade             # Upgrade installed packages
sudo apt install package     # Install a package
sudo apt remove package      # Remove a package
apt search keyword           # Search for packages



brew update                  # Update Homebrew
brew upgrade                 # Upgrade packages
brew install package         # Install a package
brew uninstall package       # Remove a package
brew search keyword          # Search for packages








Answer: You can, but youâ€™ll face challenges:

Environment Mismatch: Production servers run Linux. Developing on Windows means your code might behave differently when deployed.
Tool Compatibility: Many development tools, Docker containers, and scripts are designed for Unix-like systems.
Path Differences: Windows uses C:\path\to\file, Unix uses /path/to/file. This causes bugs.
Line Endings: Windows uses CRLF (\r\n), Unix uses LF (\n). This breaks scripts and causes git conflicts.

Best Practice: Use WSL2 on Windows to get a real Linux environment.




Answer:







Term
Definition




Terminal
The application/window where you type commands


Shell
The program that interprets your commands (bash, zsh)


Console
Originally physical hardware; now used interchangeably with terminal



Think of it like: - Terminal = The browser window - Shell = The website/application running inside




Answer: sudo stands for â€œSuperUser DOâ€. It grants temporary root (administrator) privileges.
# Regular user - can't modify system files
apt install git         # âŒ Permission denied

# With sudo - runs as root
sudo apt install git    # âœ… Works
Why This Exists: - Security: Prevents accidental system damage - Audit: Logs who ran privileged commands - Multi-user: Limits what each user can do




Answer:

â”‚                      COMPARISON                              â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¬â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚               â”‚ Virtual Machine â”‚ Container   â”‚ WSL2        â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¼â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚ Isolation     â”‚ Complete        â”‚ Process     â”‚ OS-level    â”‚
â”‚ Has Own OS?   â”‚ Yes (full)      â”‚ No (shared) â”‚ Yes (Linux) â”‚
â”‚ Startup       â”‚ Minutes         â”‚ Seconds     â”‚ Seconds     â”‚
â”‚ Resources     â”‚ Heavy           â”‚ Light       â”‚ Light       â”‚
â”‚ Use Case      â”‚ Full isolation  â”‚ App deploy  â”‚ Dev environ â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”´â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜

VM: Like a separate computer running inside yours
Container: Like a lightweight, isolated app package
WSL2: Linux running alongside Windows, sharing resources





Answer: POSIX (Portable Operating System Interface) is a standard that defines how Unix-like operating systems should behave.
Why It Matters: - Code written for one POSIX system works on others - macOS, Linux, BSD are all POSIX-compliant - Windows is NOT POSIX-compliant (hence the differences)
Example: A shell script written on macOS will work on Linux because both follow POSIX standards.




Answer: Package managers like apt provide:



Benefit
Explanation




Security
Packages are verified and signed


Dependencies
Automatically installs required libraries


Updates
One command updates everything


Consistency
Everyone gets the same version


Cleanup
Easy to remove with all components



# Instead of downloading Python from website:
sudo apt install python3

# Update ALL software at once:
sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade




Answer:



File
When It Runs




.bash_profile
Login shells (when you first log in)


.bashrc
Non-login shells (new terminal windows)



Best Practice: Put your configurations in .bashrc and source it from .bash_profile:
# In .bash_profile
if [ -f ~/.bashrc ]; then
    source ~/.bashrc
fi
For zsh users: Use .zshrc (itâ€™s simpler - one file for everything).




Answer: Follow these guidelines:



Command
Safety Level
Notes




ls, pwd, cat
ğŸŸ¢ Safe
Read-only commands


mkdir, touch
ğŸŸ¢ Safe
Creates files/dirs


cp, mv
ğŸŸ¡ Caution
Can overwrite files


rm
ğŸ”´ Dangerous
Deletes permanently


rm -rf
â›” Very Dangerous
No confirmation, recursive


sudo rm -rf /
â˜ ï¸ NEVER
Destroys your system



Tips: 1. Use ls before rm to see what youâ€™re deleting 2. Use rm -i for confirmation prompts 3. Never run commands you donâ€™t understand 4. Be extra careful with sudo




Answer: You probably set a variable in the current session but didnâ€™t save it.
Session vs Permanent:
# This ONLY works in current session
export MY_VAR="hello"

# To make it permanent, add to your shell config
echo 'export MY_VAR="hello"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc  # Apply immediately




Answer:








Symbol
Meaning
Example




/
Root of entire filesystem
/etc/hosts


~
Your home directory
~/Documents = /home/username/Documents


.
Current directory
./script.sh


..
Parent directory
cd ..










# 1. Go to your home directory
# 2. Create a folder called "tds-practice"
# 3. Inside it, create three files: file1.txt, file2.txt, file3.txt
# 4. List all files with details
# 5. Go back to home directory in one command



# 1. Display your current PATH
# 2. Create an environment variable called "MY_NAME" with your name
# 3. Print it
# 4. Make it permanent by adding to ~/.bashrc



# 1. Create a file called "secret.txt"
# 2. Check its current permissions
# 3. Make it readable only by you (owner)
# 4. Verify the change





By now, you should understand:

Why TDS uses Linux/Unix
Key differences between Windows and Unix
What VMs and WSL are
How to set up macOS (Terminal + Homebrew)
How to set up WSL2 on Windows
Why emulators are problematic
Basic Linux commands and concepts






Ubuntu WSL Documentation
Homebrew Documentation
Linux Command Line Basics
The Missing Semester (MIT)





Feel free to ask any questions about: - Environment setup issues - Linux commands - WSL configuration - macOS Terminal usage

End of Session 1: Environment Setup

text: Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) enables you to run a Linux environment directly on Windowsâ€”no virtual machine or dual-boot required.

title: WSL - Windows Subsystem for Linux
text: Windows Subsystem for Linux (WSL) enables you to run a Linux environment directly on Windowsâ€”no virtual machine or dual-boot required.

title: WSL - Windows Subsystem for Linux
text:
Setup Steps

Step 1: Enable Virtualization in BIOS
Access your BIOS settings and enable Virtualization Technology (VT-x/AMD-V).


Step 2: Enable Windows Features

Search for â€œTurn Windows features on or offâ€
Enable the following features:

âœ… Virtual Machine Platform
âœ… Windows Hypervisor Platform
âœ… Windows Subsystem for Linux

Restart your computer



Step 3: Install WSL Distribution
Open PowerShell or Command Prompt as Administrator:
# List available Linux distributions
wsl --list --online

# Install your preferred distribution (e.g., Ubuntu)
wsl --install -d <DistroName>


Step 4: Verify Installation
# Check installed distributions and their status
wsl --list --verbose

title: WSL - Windows Subsystem for Linux
text:
Useful Commands
# Uninstall a distribution
wsl --unregister <DistroName>

# Set default WSL version
wsl --set-default-version 2

# Update WSL
wsl --update

title: Linux Navigation & File System
text:
Navigation Commands
pwd     # Print present working directory
ls      # List files/folders (excludes hidden)
ls -a   # List all files/folders (includes hidden)

cd - Change Directory
# Absolute path (starts from root /)
cd /home/username/projects

# Relative path (from current location)
cd projects       # current â†’ projects folder
cd ./projects     # same as above
cd ../documents   # current â†’ parent â†’ documents folder
cd ../            # current â†’ parent folder
cd ../../         # current â†’ grandparent folder

# Shortcuts
cd ~              # Go to user home directory, /home/username
cd                # Same as cd ~
cd -              # Go to OLDPWD

Hidden Files: .xyz vs ./xyz



Notation
Meaning




cd .xyz
cd to folder with name .xyz in current directory


cd ./xyz
cd to folder with name xyz in current directory



ls -a          # Show hidden files
./script.sh    # Execute script in current folder

title: Linux Navigation & File System
text:
Creating Files & Folders

touch - Create Empty File
touch file.txt                      # Create single file
touch file1.txt file2.txt           # Create multiple files
touch ~/projects/newfile.py         # Create in specific path


mkdir - Make Directory
mkdir myfolder                      # Create folder
mkdir -p projects/python/app        # Create nested folders
mkdir folder1 folder2               # Create multiple folders

title: Linux Navigation & File System
text:
Removing Files & Folders

rm - Remove Files
rm file.txt             # Remove file
rm -i file.txt          # Remove with confirmation
rm -f file.txt          # Force remove (no confirmation)


rmdir - Remove Empty Directory
rmdir emptyfolder       # Remove empty folder only (fails if not empty)


rm -r - Remove Directory Recursively
rm -r myfolder          # Remove folder and all contents
rm -rf myfolder         # Force remove without confirmation

âš ï¸ Warning: rm -rf is dangerous! Double-check before using.

title: Linux Navigation & File System
text:
Quick Reference
# Navigation
pwd                     # Print current path
cd /path/to/dir         # Go to directory
cd ~                    # Go to home
cd ..                   # Go up one level
cd -                    # Go to previous directory

# Viewing
ls                      # List files
ls -la                  # List all with details

# Creating
touch file.txt          # Create file
mkdir folder            # Create folder
mkdir -p a/b/c          # Create nested folders

# Removing
rm file.txt             # Remove file
rmdir folder            # Remove empty folder
rm -r folder            # Remove folder with contents

Path Symbols Summary



Symbol
Meaning




/
Root directory


~
Home directory


.
Current directory


..
Parent directory


-
Previous directory (with cd)

title: Developer Common Tools Installation
text:
Quick Setup Script
# System update
sudo apt update && sudo apt upgrade -y

# Essential tools
sudo apt install curl git -y

# C/C++ Development Tools
sudo apt install build-essential -y

# Java Development Kit
sudo apt install default-jdk -y
echo 'export JAVA_HOME="/usr/lib/jvm/default-java"' >> ~/.bashrc

# Python (UV), Node.js, Podman - See installation links below
# UV â†’ https://docs.astral.sh/uv/#installation
# Node â†’ https://nodejs.org/en/download
# Podman â†’ https://podman.io/docs/installation

# Virtual Machine (KVM/QEMU)
sudo apt install qemu-kvm libvirt-daemon-system libvirt-clients bridge-utils virt-manager -y
sudo systemctl enable libvirtd && sudo systemctl start libvirtd
sudo usermod -aG libvirt,kvm $USER

# Restart to apply changes
sudo reboot

title: Program & Path
text:
Where Does $PATH Come From?

1ï¸âƒ£ OS and Shell Design
Linux and shells (like Bash) are designed to:

Look at the $PATH variable
Search directories from left to right
Execute the first matching executable file




2ï¸âƒ£ Shell Startup Files

.bashrc

Runs every time you open a new terminal
Common place to modify $PATH

Example:
export PATH="$PATH:$HOME/bin"
This means:

The change applies to every new terminal
Not to already-open terminals

title: Shell & Environment Variables
text: Understanding shells, configuration files, and environment variables in Linuxâ€”essential knowledge for any developer.

title: Shell & Environment Variables
text:
What is a Shell?
A shell is a command-line interface that interprets your commands and communicates with the operating system.
Common Shells:

Bash (Bourne Again Shell) - Default on most Linux systems
Zsh (Z Shell) - Feature-rich with better auto-completion
Fish - User-friendly with helpful suggestions

# Check your current shell
echo $SHELL

# List all available shells
cat /etc/shells

# Change default shell to Zsh
chsh -s /usr/bin/zsh

title: Shell & Environment Variables
text:
Shell Types

1. Login Shell
Started when you log in (SSH, initial terminal).

Reads profile files (.bash_profile, .profile)
Sets up initial environment



2. Interactive Shell
A shell where you type commands and get responses.

Reads rc files (.bashrc, .zshrc)
Has command history and tab completion



3. Non-Interactive Shell
Runs scripts without user interaction.

Uses $BASH_ENV variable (if set)
No command history

# Check if shell is interactive (look for 'i')
echo $-

# Check if login shell (output starts with '-')
echo $0

File
When Used
Purpose

$BASH_ENV

bash starts

title: Shell & Environment Variables
text:
Variables: Shell vs Environment

Shell Variables (Local)
Variables that exist only in the current shell.
# Create a shell variable
MY_VAR="Hello"

# Access it
echo $MY_VAR

# NOT available to child processes
bash -c 'echo $MY_VAR'  # Output: (empty)


Environment Variables (Global)
Variables exported to child processes.
# Create and export
export MY_VAR="Hello"

# Available to child processes
bash -c 'echo $MY_VAR'  # Output: Hello

# Python can access it too
python3 -c "import os; print(os.environ.get('MY_VAR'))"


Why Export?
Without export:
Parent Shell: MY_VAR="value"
       â†“
Child Process: MY_VAR not available âŒ
With export:
Parent Shell: export MY_VAR="value"
       â†“
Child Process: MY_VAR="value" âœ…

title: Shell & Environment Variables
text:
Common Environment Variables
# View all environment variables
printenv

# Important variables
echo $HOME          # Home directory
echo $USER          # Username
echo $PATH          # Executable search paths
echo $SHELL         # Default shell
echo $PWD           # Current directory

Setting Environment Variables
# Temporary (current session only)
export JAVA_HOME="/usr/lib/jvm/default-java"

# Permanent (add to ~/.bashrc)
echo 'export JAVA_HOME="/usr/lib/jvm/default-java"' >> ~/.bashrc
source ~/.bashrc

title: Shell & Environment Variables
text:
Source vs Export

source Command
Executes commands in the current shell (not a new shell).
# Reload configuration
source ~/.bashrc

# Shorthand
. ~/.bashrc
Flow:
Current Shell
    â†“
source ~/.bashrc
    â†“
Commands run in SAME shell
    â†“
Changes apply immediately


export Command
Makes variables available to child processes.
# Export variable
export API_KEY="secret123"

# Child processes can access it
python3 script.py  # Can read API_KEY
Flow:
Parent Shell
    â†“
export VAR=value
    â†“
Child Process starts
    â†“
VAR is accessible in child

title: Shell & Environment Variables
text:
How Programs Inherit Environment
When you run a program, it inherits environment variables from the shell:
Interactive bash running
        â†“
User types: python3 app.py
        â†“
bash searches for python3 in $PATH
        â†“
bash creates child process (fork)
        â†“
execve(python3, ["app.py"], environment)
        â†“
Python starts with inherited environment
        â†“
app.py can access environment variables

Practical Example
In Shell:
# Set environment variable in ~/.bashrc
export DATABASE_URL="postgresql://localhost/mydb"
source ~/.bashrc
In Python (app.py):
import os

# Access environment variable
db_url = os.environ.get('DATABASE_URL')
print(f"Database: {db_url}")
Run:
python3 app.py
# Output: Database: postgresql://localhost/mydb

title: Shell & Environment Variables
text:
Quick Reference
# Shell information
echo $SHELL                 # Default shell
echo $0                     # Current shell
cat /etc/shells             # Available shells

# Variables
VAR=value                   # Shell variable (local)
export VAR=value            # Environment variable (global)
printenv                    # List all environment variables
echo $VAR                   # Print variable value

# Configuration
source ~/.bashrc            # Reload configuration
nano ~/.bashrc              # Edit configuration

Key Concepts

Login shell â†’ Reads profile files (.bash_profile, .zprofile)
Interactive shell â†’ Reads rc files (.bashrc, .zshrc)
Non-interactive shell â†’ Uses $BASH_ENV (if set)
export â†’ Share variable with child processes
source â†’ Run commands in current shell
Shell variable â†’ Local to current shell only
Environment variable â†’ Inherited by child processes

title: Running Commands & Scripts
text: How Linux shell interprets and executes commands.

title: Running Commands & Scripts
text: How Linux shell interprets and executes commands.

title: Running Commands & Scripts
text:
How Shell Executes Commands
When you type a command, shell parses it into parts:
command arg1 arg2 -flag --option
   â†“      â†“    â†“    â†“      â†“
program  arguments  options/flags

Examples
ls -l /home              # command: ls, flag: -l, arg: /home
cp file1.txt file2.txt   # command: cp, args: file1.txt, file2.txt
python3 script.py -v     # command: python3, arg: script.py, flag: -v
git commit -m "message"  # command: git, subcommand: commit, option: -m with value


Command Resolution
User types: xyz
     â†“
Shell searches $PATH directories
     â†“
Found? â†’ Execute it
Not found? â†’ "command not found"

title: Running Commands & Scripts
text:
Running a Script

Create & Run
# 1. Create script
touch myscript.sh

# 2. Add content (with shebang)
nano myscript.sh # write the `echo "hello"`

# 3. Make executable
chmod +x myscript.sh

# 4. Run it
./myscript.sh


chmod Reference
chmod +x file       # Add execute permission
chmod -x file       # Remove execute permission
chmod 755 file      # rwx for owner, rx for others

title: Running Commands & Scripts
text:
PATH vs Provided Path
How Linux decides where to look for the command:



Command
Contains / or ./?
Action




xyz
No
Search in $PATH


./xyz
Yes (.)
Look in current directory


/usr/bin/xyz
Yes (/)
Look at exact path



python3          # No slash â†’ Search $PATH
./myscript.sh    # Has ./ â†’ Run from current dir
/bin/ls          # Absolute path â†’ Run exactly this

Useful Commands
# Check your IP address
ip addr show          # Linux/WSL
ipconfig              # Windows (in PowerShell)

# Check WSL IP specifically
hostname -I           # In WSL

# Check what ports are in use
netstat -tulpn        # Linux
netstat -an           # Windows

# Test connectivity
ping google.com
ping 192.168.1.1      # Your router


ğŸ§ª Try It Yourself: Test Network Connectivity
# Step 1: Can you reach the internet?
ping -c 4 google.com
# If this works, your internet is fine!

# Step 2: Check your WSL/Linux IP
hostname -I
# Example output: 172.25.160.1

# Step 3: From Windows, can you ping WSL?
# Open PowerShell and run:
ping 172.25.160.1
What Success Looks Like:
PING google.com (142.250.190.46) 56(84) bytes of data.
64 bytes from 142.250.190.46: icmp_seq=1 ttl=117 time=15.2 ms
64 bytes from 142.250.190.46: icmp_seq=2 ttl=117 time=14.8 ms

--- google.com ping statistics ---
4 packets transmitted, 4 received, 0% packet loss

ğŸ’¡ If ping fails: Check if youâ€™re connected to WiFi, or try ping 8.8.8.8 (Googleâ€™s DNS server)

title: Session 2: Networking and the Web
text:
Step 1: Create a FastAPI Server
# Install FastAPI and Uvicorn
pip install fastapi uvicorn
Create main.py:
from fastapi import FastAPI

# Create the app
app = FastAPI(title="My First API")

# Root endpoint
@app.get("/")
def read_root():
    return {"message": "Hello, TDS Students! ğŸ‘‹"}

# Get item by ID
@app.get("/items/{item_id}")
def read_item(item_id: int, q: str = None):
    return {
        "item_id": item_id, 
        "query": q
    }

# POST example
@app.post("/items")
def create_item(name: str, price: float):
    return {
        "name": name,
        "price": price,
        "status": "created"
    }
Run the server:
uvicorn main:app --reload --host 0.0.0.0 --port 8000
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”

title: Session 2: Networking and the Web
text:
Step 2: Set Up Ngrok

Install Ngrok
# Ubuntu/WSL
sudo snap install ngrok

# OR download from ngrok.com and add to PATH

# macOS
brew install ngrok


Create a Free Account

Go to https://ngrok.com
Sign up for free
Get your auth token from dashboard



Configure Ngrok
ngrok config add-authtoken YOUR_AUTH_TOKEN_HERE


Start the Tunnel
# In a NEW terminal (keep FastAPI running)
ngrok http 8000

What is curl?
curl (Client URL) is a command-line tool for making HTTP requests.

title: Session 2: Networking and the Web
text:
GET Requests
# Simple GET request
curl http://localhost:8000/

# GET with query parameters
curl "http://localhost:8000/items/42?q=search"

# GET with headers
curl -H "Accept: application/json" http://localhost:8000/

# Show response headers
curl -i http://localhost:8000/

# Verbose (debug) mode
curl -v http://localhost:8000/

title: Session 2: Networking and the Web
text:
POST Requests
# POST with JSON body
curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/items \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"name": "Widget", "price": 29.99}'

# POST with form data
curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/login \
  -d "username=john&password=secret"

# POST from file
curl -X POST http://localhost:8000/items \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d @data.json

title: Session 2: Networking and the Web
text:
PUT and DELETE
# PUT (update)
curl -X PUT http://localhost:8000/items/123 \
  -H "Content-Type: application/json" \
  -d '{"name": "New Name", "price": 39.99}'

# DELETE
curl -X DELETE http://localhost:8000/items/123

ğŸ§ª Try It Yourself: Hit a Public API!
You donâ€™t need your own server to practice curl! Try these real APIs:
# 1. Get a random joke
curl https://official-joke-api.appspot.com/random_joke
# Output: {"setup":"Why did the scarecrow win an award?","punchline":"He was outstanding in his field."}

# 2. Get your public IP address
curl https://api.ipify.org?format=json
# Output: {"ip":"103.xx.xx.xx"}

# 3. Get GitHub user info
curl https://api.github.com/users/torvalds
# Shows Linus Torvalds' GitHub profile!

# 4. Get a random cat fact
curl https://catfact.ninja/fact
# Output: {"fact":"A cat's brain is...", "length":...}

# 5. Check if a website is up
curl -I -s https://google.com | head -1
# HTTP/2 200  (means it's working!)

ğŸ’¡ Pro tip: Add | jq at the end to pretty-print JSON (install with sudo apt install jq)

title: Session 2: Networking and the Web
text:
Practical Examples
# Test your FastAPI server
curl http://localhost:8000/
# Output: {"message":"Hello, TDS Students! ğŸ‘‹"}

# Get item with query
curl "http://localhost:8000/items/5?q=test"
# Output: {"item_id":5,"query":"test"}

# Hit a public API
curl https://api.github.com/users/octocat

# Download a file
curl -o image.jpg https://example.com/image.jpg

# Follow redirects
curl -L http://github.com

# With authentication
curl -H "Authorization: Bearer your_token" https://api.example.com/user

title: Session 2: Networking and the Web
text:
curl Output Formatting
# Pretty print JSON (pipe to jq)
curl http://localhost:8000/ | jq

# Save response to file
curl -o response.json http://localhost:8000/

# Only show HTTP status code
curl -s -o /dev/null -w "%{http_code}" http://localhost:8000/

title: Session 2: Networking and the Web
section: Q2: Why canâ€™t I access my local server from another device?
text:
Q2: Why canâ€™t I access my local server from another device?
Answer: Multiple reasons:

Binding to localhost - Server only listens on 127.0.0.1
Firewall - Blocking incoming connections
NAT - Your router doesnâ€™t forward traffic

Solutions: - Use --host 0.0.0.0 to bind to all interfaces - Open port in firewall - Use Ngrok for public access

Q5: What is REST API?
REST (Representational State Transfer) is an architectural style for APIs.

â”‚                        REST PRINCIPLES                                   â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤

â”‚   1. STATELESS                                                           â”‚
â”‚      Each request contains all info needed; server doesn't remember     â”‚
â”‚                                                                          â”‚
â”‚   2. RESOURCE-BASED                                                      â”‚
â”‚      URLs represent resources: /users, /products, /orders               â”‚
â”‚                                                                          â”‚
â”‚   3. HTTP METHODS = ACTIONS                                             â”‚
â”‚      GET = Read, POST = Create, PUT = Update, DELETE = Remove           â”‚
â”‚                                                                          â”‚
â”‚   4. STANDARD STATUS CODES                                              â”‚
â”‚      200 = OK, 404 = Not Found, 500 = Server Error                      â”‚
â”‚                                                                          â”‚

title: Session 2: Networking and the Web
section: Q6: Why do we need Ngrok instead of just using our IP?
text:
Q6: Why do we need Ngrok instead of just using our IP?
Answer:
â”Œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”
â”‚                     WHY NOT JUST USE YOUR IP?                            â”‚
â”œâ”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”¤
â”‚                                                                          â”‚
â”‚   PROBLEM 1: Private IP                                                  â”‚
â”‚   Your IP (192.168.x.x) is PRIVATE - not accessible from internet       â”‚
â”‚                                                                          â”‚
â”‚   PROBLEM 2: NAT/Router                                                  â”‚
â”‚   Router doesn't know which device to forward requests to               â”‚
â”‚                                                                          â”‚
â”‚   PROBLEM 3: Dynamic IP                                                  â”‚
â”‚   Your public IP changes regularly (unless you pay for static IP)       â”‚
â”‚                                                                          â”‚
â”‚   PROBLEM 4: Firewall                                                    â”‚
â”‚   ISP might block incoming connections                                   â”‚
â”‚                                                                          â”‚
â”‚   PROBLEM 5: No HTTPS                                                    â”‚
â”‚   You'd need SSL certificates for secure connections                     â”‚
â”‚                                                                          â”‚
â”‚   â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€     â”‚
â”‚                                                                          â”‚
â”‚   NGROK SOLVES ALL OF THIS:                                             â”‚
â”‚   âœ“ Gives you a public URL                                              â”‚
â”‚   âœ“ Handles NAT traversal                                               â”‚
â”‚   âœ“ Static subdomain (paid) or random (free)                            â”‚
â”‚   âœ“ Bypasses firewalls                                                   â”‚
â”‚   âœ“ Free HTTPS included                                                  â”‚
â”‚                                                                          â”‚
â””â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”˜
